thread.title: High pressure gives good viewing conditions for the northern lights
thread.title_full: High pressure gives good viewing conditions for the northern lights

author: John Jurgens
title: High pressure gives good viewing conditions for the northern lights
text:
High pressure keeps our skies nice and clear for one more night, perfect timing as the skies above get a little more active in a different and more spectacular way.
Tonight carries a strong chance of seeing the northern lights in northern Illinois. Clear skies are in place, but some wildfire smoke overhead may make for a little murky look to the sky.
On the ground, you'll want to grab a jacket along with the camera if you're heading out to see the lights. Temperatures fall to the upper 40s and low 50s tonight.
Some high-level clouds overspread the area tomorrow as temperatures warm up. Highs reach into the mid 80s, likely just short of our record high of 88°.
Breezy south winds allows the warmer air in, but it also develops a high fire danger when combined with very dry soil and low humidity. Best advice is to avoid open burning to prevent larger wildfires.
A cold front slides through early Saturday morning, starting a big cooldown into next week. The front stalls just to our south as a low pressure system slides in from the southwest, setting up a slight chance for rain.
A few spotty showers are possible mainly east of I-39, Saturday afternoon and evening with low rainfall amounts expected. Otherwise, highs fall to around 70° on Saturday, 60s on Sunday, then mid 50s to complete a 30° cooldown through Monday and Tuesday.
